snippet: Prison breakouts in Iraq have freed hundreds of militants who have joined radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and in Iraq itself.
abstract: Series of daring breakouts from Iraqi prisons has freed hundreds of hardened militants who are now among the leaders and foot soldiers of radical Sunni groups operating in Syrian insurgency; former inmates are fueling new wave of jihad across region, unfortunate reminder of the breakdown in authority in Iraq following departure of American troops in 2011.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Reporting was contributed by Duraid Adnan and Yasir Ghazi from Baghdad, Karam Shoumali from Istanbul, and employees of The New York Times from Anbar and Diyala Provinces, Iraq.

lead_paragraph: Prison breakouts in Iraq have freed hundreds of militants who have joined radical Sunni groups operating in neighboring Syria and in Iraq itself.

headline.main: Escaped Inmates From Iraq Fuel Syrian Insurgency
headline.print_headline: Escaped Inmates From Iraq Fuel Syria Insurgency
